Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A serious conflict with teammates is threatening the mentee’s deliverable timeline.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: Management needs firm estimates for the quarterly roadmap and is awaiting their input
Story: I stared at my inbox, the cursor blinking accusingly in the draft to my mentor. As a mentee, I knew I was supposed to be open about the conflict brewing with my teammates—our arguments over task ownership had already delayed our deliverables. My mentor always said, “Tell me early if you hit a wall.” But as an engineer, I was also expected to join the project planning call in ten minutes and give management a solid estimate for the next quarter. They needed numbers, not excuses, and I could already hear the impatience in their last email. My mind raced: if I told my mentor, it might help, but it would also mean admitting I couldn’t keep the project on track. If I focused on the planning call, I’d have to fudge the estimates, knowing the conflict made any timeline a guess. My stomach twisted as I weighed honesty against responsibility, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in, demanding different things at the same time.
